title.narrative: IIDH- Capacity Building Environmental Rights and SRHR
IIDH- Capacity Building Environmental Rights and SRHR

description.narrative: Decision makers, public officials, private sector and civil society incorporate in their political decisions, services, productive operations and demands (respectively), a human rights approach as related to environmental and sexual and reproductive health rights, especially in regards to vulnerable groups. The project seeks to promote among right holders and duty bearers use of human rights protection mechanisms which are based on regional and international human rights standards. It pretends to provide rights holders with access to information, participation in decision-making and access to justice, when affected by discrimination, exclusion and lack of state policies protecting their rights to environment, respect for sexual and reproductive health rights, and access to justice. Additionally, it seeks to provide duty bearers methodological tools to help guarantee respect for environment, sexual and reproductive health rights and access to justice.

Det Interamerikanska Institutet för Mänskliga Rättigheter (IIHR) är en oberoende internationell akademisk institution, skapad år 1980 enligt ett internationellt avtal mellan den Interamerikanska Domstolen för de mänskliga rättigheterna och Costa Rica. Dess uppgift är att främja och stärka respekten för de mänskliga rättigheterna såsom de fastställs i den Interamerikanska Konventionen om mänskliga rättigheter och andra fördrag och bidra till konsolidering av demokratin i regionen genom utredningar, utbildning, tekniskt stöd, medling, informationsspridning och kommunikation. IIHR genomför projekt på nationell och regional nivå för medborgarna i Latinamerika ska ha bättra kapacitet att häva dessa rättigheter, för att staterna ska känna och utöva till sina skyldigheter och för att de mellanstatliga institutionerna bätttre ska kunna skydda dessa rättigheter och ställa stater till ansvar .
År 2017 mottog Sveriges ambassad i Guatemala en delegering av medel från den globala strategin för särskilda initiativ om mänskliga rättigheter och demokratisering för att stärka de mänskliga rättigheterna i Honduras och El Salvador. Mänskliga rättigheter kopplade till natturresurser och sexuella och reproduktiva rättigheter har identifierats som särskilt sårbara i Honduras och El Salvador. Det är också områden där det krävs ett fördjupat arbete för att tolka och tydliggöra jurisprudens och internationella standards, samt där kapacietet och kunskap har identifierats som låg.
IIHR har lång erfarenhet av kunskapshöjande insatser och en hög trovärdighet hos olika aktörer i regionen, både inom det civila samhället, rättsvårdande institutioner och internationella organisationer. IIHR föreslås därför ingå samarbetsavtal med Sveriges ambassad i Guatemala. Huvudsyftet är att tillgången information och kunskapen hos beslutsfattare, rättsväsendet och civila samhällsorganisationer och på så sätt i förlängningen öka möjligheten till rättvisa för utsatta grupper som drabbas av diskriminering, marginalisering och vars rättigheter.
Bland de förväntade resultaten är följande: - Statliga institutioner, privata företag och organisationer i det civila samhället underlättar och efterfrågar tillgång till rättslig prövning vad gäller miljörättigheter och SRHR - Organisationer i det civila samhället har nödvändiga färdigheter inom organisation, utbildning, förespråkare och försvar för att utöva sin rätt till information, deltagande och rättvisa i juridiska frågor som innefattar miljö och SRHR - Försvarare utövar sin rätt att främja och skydda mänskliga rättigheter i samband med miljö, landrättigheter, deltagande och SRHR - Offentliga tjänstemän är medvetna om och införlivar SRHR och kvinnors tillgång till rättvisa i tillhandahållandet av offentliga tjänster
Insatsen bidrar till att möta nya utmaningar i mänskliga rättigheter genom att främja skydd av miljörättigheter och SRHR och deras försvar i Honduras, El Salvador och Guatemala.

The Inter-American Institute of Human Rights (IIDH) is an independent international academic institution, created in 1980 under an international agreement between the Inter-American Court of Human Rights and the Republic of Costa Rica. Its mission is to promote and strengthen respect for human rights established in the Inter-American Convention on Human Rights and other treaties, and to contribute to consolidation of democracy in the region through education, investigation, training, technical assistance, mediation and communication. IIDH supports the Inter-American system of international human rights protection and executes local and regional projects for the dissemination of these rights among the principal non-governmental organizations and public institutions of the Americas, serving as a bridge between States and the civil society.
In 2017, the Embassy of Sweden in Guatemala received from Sida a delegation of regional funds of the global strategy for special initiatives on human rights and democratisation to initiate cooperation in Honduras and El Salvador. Among the selected partners to carry out regional human rights work is IIDH, which enters into cooperation agreement with the Embassy of Sweden in Guatemala to promote among duty bearers and rights holders mechanisms and regional and universal standards of protection of environment, sexual and reproductive rights and related rights, which will improve access to information, to decision making and to justice of vulnerable groups affected by discrimination, exclusion and non-protection.
Among the expected results are the following: - State institutions, private companies and civil society organizations facilitate and demand (respectively), access to justice in environmental and sexual and reproductive rights - civil society organizations have the necessary skills in organization, training, advocacy and defence to exercise their right to information, participation and justice in legal matter related to environment, and reproductive rights - defenders exercise their right to promote and protect human rights related to environment, territory, participation and sexual and reproductive rights - public officials are aware of and incorporate sexual and reproductive rights and women's access to justice into provision of public services
The intervention contributes to facing new challenges in human rights by promoting protection of environmental and sexual and reproductive rights, and their defence in Honduras and El Salvador.

description.narrative: During the follow-up period IIDH reported various concrete results in promotion and protection of environmental and sexual and reproductive health rights. As a means of achieving the desired change, IIDH carried out actions to promote the above mentioned rights both among duty bearers and rights holders, strengthening capacities of personnel in state ministries, human rights ombudsman's institutions, legislative assemblies, private businesses and civil society organizations. Concrete examples of results related to promotion and protection of the environment include the following: - The National Human Rights Commissioner of Honduras has benefited from IIDH publication "Socialenvironmental problems in Honduras and Guatemala: Justice, protection and defense at the national and Inter-American levels" to argue cases based on Inter-American System of Human Rights standards thus improving protection of environmental defenders and activists - through the above mentioned publication, promotion of Inter-American environmental protection standards has produced investigation and application of the standards in University of Cuenca (Ecuador), Autonomous University of Chiapas, and Autonomous University of Queretaro, and a proposal to regulate a free and informed prior consultation for land use in indigenous regions in Honduras - The Human Rights Commission of Mexico City has incorporated the contents of the publication in its Diploma Program on Human Rights, the Environment and Mobility in Mexico City - promotion of social audit among civil society and state institutions as legitimate form of citizen participation and the obligation of authorities to provide access to information related to public administration of natural resources. Seven teams of citizen auditors to demand transparency and accountability from authorities have been created through online training and capacity building. Results related to promotion and protection of sexual and reproductive health rights include: - an IIDH publication "Sexual and Reproductive Rights Compliance Indicator System" has served the Department of National Reality of the Salvadoran HR Ombudsman's institution in preparation of institutional reports and declarations, and in reports to international human rights bodies concerned with protecting women criminalized for obstetric emergencies in El Salvador - a course on strategic litigation, legislative lobbying and argumentation techniques for access to justice for women criminalized by obstetric emergencies was carried out in El Salvador, with participation of judges from the Constitutional Courtroom of the Supreme Court of El Salvador, contributing to improved technical capacities to analyze and prepare resolutions and sentences in cases presented by women criminalized for obstetric emergencies - the technical team of Salvadoran Legislative Assembly's Commission of Women and Equality benefited from the above mentioned publication for study on initiative to reform the Special Comprehensive Law for a Life Free of Violence for Women and Law of Equality, Equity and Eradication of Discrimination against Women - preparation of "Ethical and Technical Guide for Treatment of Women Who Present Obstetric Emergencies", and advocacy with Ministry of Health of El Salvador for its use in training of public health workers to provide adequate health services for women in obstetric emergencies with respect and protection of their sexual and reproductive health rights according to international, universal human rights standards - civil society organizations have been instructed in strategic litigation, legislative advocacy and argumentation techniques for access to justice for women criminalized by obstetric emergencies, resulting in initiatives for defense of women criminalized for obstetric emergencies by following organizations: Red para la proteccion y atencion a mujeres victima de violencia en empresas, Comite de America Latina y EL Caribe para la defensa de los derechos humanos de las mujeres (CLADEM-Capitulo El Salvador), Asociacion Demografica Salvadorena Profamilia, Women's Link Worldwide, Fundacion Cristosal and Consejo Nacional de la Judicatura de El Salvador. These organizations are expected to participate in court hearings related to the topic at the Inter-American Court of Human Rights in the future. - IIDH has collaborated with Centro de Derechos Reproductivos and Agrupacion Ciudadana por la Despenalizacion del Aborto by providing technical tools to present judicial cases before the Inter-American System of Human Rights, invoking the American Convention of Human Rights, the Inter-American Convention to Prevent and Punish Torture and the Interamerican Convention to Prevent, Sanction and Eradicate Violence Against Women - technical training was provided to public health workers through a Course on the Inter-American System and the Universal System of Women's Human Rights, with an Emphasis on Sexual and Reproductive Rights, resulting in, for example, Ministry of Health's Unit for Comprehensive Attention to All Forms of Violence initiative to establish technical guidelines and normative processes for attending women victims of violence, including obstetric violence - through implementation of a course on Inter-American System of Women's Human Rights directed to duty bearers, including the National Police and the Human Rights Unit of the National Police of El Salvador and the Public Safety Inspectorate General, security officials have been sensitized towards violence against women, including obstetric violence, and incorporate Ethical and Technical Guide for Treatment of Women Who Present Obstetric Emergencies human rights approach in their actions - two IIDH publications, the Ethical and Technical Guide for Treatment of Women Who Present Obstetric Emergencies for health service providers and the Manual for Law Enforcement Officers, contribute directly to Inter-American Commission of Human Rights (CIDH) recommendations on the 2019 Manuela vs. El Salvador case in which CIDH found Salvadoran state responsible for violation of the victims human rights.
